oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Binding wheat in Obion County
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Wheat; Mules; Agricultural laborers; Farm produce; Harvesting machinery; Agricultural machinery & implements; Farms; Farm life
Agriculture; Wheat - Harvesting
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four individuals (male and female) binding wheat using mule-drawn equipment.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Looking Back at Tennessee Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In June, the binder would be taken through the ripe wheat fields to cut the wheat and bind it into bundles. Shocks would then be stacked by workers. Each shock was generally fourteen bundles and capped by two bundles. Following the completion of the process, the wheat would be allowed to dry in preparation for threshing.Mule-powered machinery proved revolutionary and became central to the Tennessee farm economy. Such animal-powered machines allowed farmers to dispense with much hand work.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Plowing with a team of mules
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Plowing; Mules; Muleteers; Farms; Croplands; Outbuildings; Farm life; Haystacks; Agricultural facilities; Barns; Agricultural laborers; Agricultural machinery & implements
Agriculture; Plowing; Mules
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Young man in the foreground plowing with a team of three mules. The background is filled with a haystack, farm buildings, and Wilson County farmland.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Looking Back At Tennessee Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This image highlights the importance of the mule to the development of Tennessee's farm economy. They would overtake oxen between 1870 and 1880 to become the state's main draft animals and work stock. Advances in machinery allowed for lighter and more maneuverable plows, and that contributed to the switch from the more powerful oxen to mules and horses. The relatively light wooden plow being used is most likely to be a cultivating plow, rather than a breaking plow.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Working wagon and mule team
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Mules; Carts & wagons; Men; Women; Children; Muleteers; Fences; Wooden buildings; Dirt roads
Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A team of four mules pulls a wagon along a dirt road in front of three wood frame buildings. A woman and two boys stand in the wagon. An unidentified man sits atop one of the mules.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Looking Back At Tennessee Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Mules were the key element in Tennessee’s farm economy. The extension of mule power allowed farmers to handle more land, get over their fields faster and achieve higher productivity. Although tractors made their first appearance in Tennessee during the 1920s, they were initially little more than a curiosity. It wasn’t until after World War II that mechanization replaced mules on a majority of Tennessee farms. However, many small farmers were still working with mules well into the 1950s.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: James Merrill Safford
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Men; Scientists; Geology; Teachers
Agriculture; Safford, James M. (James Merrill), 1822-1907
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving of James Merrill Safford from "Prominent Tennesseans." Containing biographies and records of many of the families who have attained prominence in Tennessee.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: William S. Speer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: James Merrill Safford was a geologist, chemist, and professor in Tennessee. Over the course of his lengthy career, he taught at Cumberland University (1848-1873), the Medical School of the University of Nashville (1873-1900) and Vanderbilt University (1875-1900). He was the state geologist from 1854 to 1900. In 1869, he authored "Geology in Tennessee." The text is still widely cited today.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dyche Family Farm
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Farms; Farmhouses; Outbuildings; Fences
Agriculture; Philadelphia (Tenn.); Loudon County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Small farm in Philadelphia, Tennessee. In the background is the farmhouse, along with several outbuildings. In the foreground is a wooden fence and telephone pole.

Philadelphia was founded in the early 1820s by William Knox and Jacob Pearson. The town initially grew quickly and prospered as a center of business in the Sweetwater Valley. By the mid-1800s, Philadelphia had two general stores,a tanning yard, a stillhouse, and a hotel. On October 20, 1863, during the Civil War, two Confederate cavalry regiments attacked and routed a Union brigade at Philadelphia while conducting maneuvers following the Battle of Chickamauga.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Threshing, near Lewisburg
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Threshing; Wheat; Men; Harvesting machinery; Agricultural machinery & implements; Mules; Farming; Grains; Hay; Mowing machines; Threshing machines; Combines (Agricultural machinery); Farming

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Robert E. Wallace
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The threshing machine (or simply thresher), was a machine first invented by Scottish mechanical engineer Andrew Meikle for use in agriculture. It was invented (c.1784) for the separation of grain from stalks and husks. Mechanization of this process took much of the drudgery out of farm labor. About 1910, horse pulled combines appeared and became a success. Later, gas and diesel engines appeared with other refinements and specifications.

Following the drying of the wheat shocks, thresher crews would arrive in the fields. Thresher equipment, run by tractor or steam engine would be set up. Workers would then gather the shocks into a wagon and take them to the threshing operation, where they would be fed into the machine. Threshing machines worked faster and supplied a cleaner product than older methods of treading out or flailing.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait Of Dr. Gerard Troost
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait paintings
Troost, Gerard, 1776-1850; Portait painting, American - 19th century
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Painted portrait of Dr. Gerard Troost, the first state geologist of Tennessee. Troost is shown standing beside a table and gesturing to a book on the table. The original portrait is now located at the Tennessee State Museum (Nashville).

Troost (1776-1850) was born in Holland and came to the United States in 1810. Two years later he became the founding president of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. After moving to Maryland and Indiana, Troost settled in Nashville in 1827 and operated the Nashville Museum of Natural History from 1827 through 1832. He served as Tennessee's state geologist from 1831 to his death in 1850. His principal employmen;, however, was the professorship of science at the University of Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Joseph Buckner Killebrew
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: People associated with agriculture; Plantation owners; Farmers' groups; Iron industry; Monuments & memorials; Journalists; Emigration & immigration; Bas-reliefs
Agriculture; Killebrew, J. B. (James Buckner), 1831-1906; Montgomery County (Tenn.)

oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Joseph Buckner Killebrew (1831-1906) was a New South advocate and Tennessee's first Commissioner of Agriculture. In his writings and speeches, he advocated the improvement and extension of public education, encouraged immigration to the South, the development of natural resources for industrialization, and improvement of agriculture, including the break up of large landholdings, the diversification of crops, enrichment of soil, and a program to attract European immigration to farm unoccupied land.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Isolated Mountain Farm in East Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Log cabins; Log buildings; Aerial views; Country life; Mountains; Farms; Agriculture; Outbuildings; Smokehouses
Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Aerial view of an isolated mountain farm in east Tennessee. The photograph shows a large log house along with several outbuildings. A fence separates the fields. A mountain road is seen as well.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Department of Conservation Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The log cabin is a familiar symbol of Tennessee's pioneer period. Although its use as shelter is well known, its quaint image has tended to obscure its importance as a bridge between civilization and the wilderness. The most important and enduring use of log construction occurred in the dwellings, barns, and related outbuildings of the thousands of independent farmsteads. Logs were used for the construction of smokehouses, tobacco barns, stock barns, and corn cribs.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Frame farmhouse
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Chimneys; Houses; Farmhouses; Porches; Wildflowers
Agriculture; Farmhouses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Angled view of the front and side of an unidentified frame farmhouse. The house is a two-story I-house with a one-story ell. The frame is covered with weatherboard. There is a covered porch on the front facade of the house.

The central-hall cottage or I-house is a common example of vernacular architecture in Tennessee dwellings. Such homes date from the early nineteenth through the late twentieth centuries. The exterior was usually frame with gabled roofs and often had gable end chimneys. The interior consisted of a central hall with symmetrical rooms to either side.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Corn Shocks at Unidentified Home in Robertson County
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Corn; Corn shocks; Farm life; Harvesting; Farms
Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified home in Robertson County, Tennessee. In the foreground are several corn shocks and a cleared field.

By 1840 Tennessee was the leading corn-producing state in the Union, with 12 percent of the nation's total. Ten years later, the state grew enough corn to feed its three million hogs, the most in the nation. Corn continued to play a prominent role in post-Civil War agriculture, although prices did not recover to their pre-war level for several decades. In autumn, when the ears of corn were ripe, farmers cut the stalks of corn and stacked them in shocks in the field.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ferries; Marine terminals; Boats; Flatboats; Barges; Rivers; Mountains; Cattle; Farms
Agriculture; Chattanooga (Tenn.); Hamilton County (Tenn.); Tennessee River.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ferry in Chattanooga, Tennessee. The etching shows the operation of an active ferry. In the drawing are cattle being ferried across the river. There are some small boats and trees in the foreground. There are also hills and a farm in the background.

Due to lack of road building, the need for reliable river crossings became evident. Ferry boats operated by individuals soon appeared at major river crossings. Some 700 to 1,000 ferries operated in Tennessee in the 19th century. The Tennessee River landing and ferry operation of John and Lewis Ross becames Ross's Landing, the forerunner of Chattanooga.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Fearless Railway Thrashing Machines
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Agriculture
Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A fold-out chart, with illustrations, of threshing and other farm equipment manufactured by Minard Harder of Cobleskill, N.Y. Included is price chart, testimonials of satisfied customers, and illustraions of the awards won by the Minard Harder company. The pamphlet was distributed by the company's General Southern Agent,George W. Stockwell of Nashville, Tennessee. Included is a separate fold-out illustrating the equipment availbale through Stockwell.

The widespread use of horse-powered threshing machines exemplifies the adoption of labor-saving machinery in Tennessee in the post-Civil War era. These machines separated small grain from the stems faster than treading or flailing while producing a cleaner product. Although cost was a defintie factor, more and more farmers were rejecting the traditional agricultural methods and Tennessee became a flourishing market for horse-powered farm implements.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Agriculture
Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A fifty-six page catalogue pertaining to the manufacturing of sorghum in Tennessee with detailed descriptions of various machinery utilized in the production of sorghum. The full title is "Southern Sorgo Manual: Containing a Catalogue of Cane Mills, Evaporators and Cane Juice Clarifiers." The pamphlet is rich in illustrations of the devices used to process the sorghum plant into syrup and sugar. There are segments of the catalogue devoted to the various steps in making sugar.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Southern Sorgo Machine Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sorghum is a member of the grass family introduced into the United States in 1853. Sorghum also refers to the syrup produced from the juice extracted when the sorghum plant is boiled. The sorghum industry became widespread in the South about the time of the Civil War when food supplies became scarce. The stalks of the sorghum plant were also used for fodder. Today Tennessee and Kentucky are the leading producers of sorghum.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Forest Nursery Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Forest Nursery Company was founded by J. H. H. Boyd in 1887. He located his wholesale nursery business in McMinnville in 1904 and specialized in forest and shade trees, evergreens, and ornamental shrubs. His sons James R. and Fernando C. Boyd assisted him and continued the business after his death in 1924. It is still vital today. J. H. H. Boyd is often referred to as the father of the nursery industry in Warren County, and Warren County is referred to as "The Nursery Capital of the World."

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From earliest times,Warren County's landscape was heavily populated with oak, chestnut, beech and other nut trees. Jonathan H. H. Boyd, founder of Forest Nursery Company, took note and focused on forest and shade trees and prevailed over those nurseries who focused on apple trees instead. Note that the American chestnut is still being offered for sale at this time;this is prior to the full impact of the chestnut blight that appeared in the U.S. in 1904 and wiped out the U.S. Chestnut trees.

oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Charles Waring & Co.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map demonstrates the rich mineral resources available for potential manufacturers in Tennessee during the nineteenth century. At the time, northern investors were purchasing huge acreages in mineral rich areas of Appalachia. Tennessee was an early leader in iron ore production. However, by the beginning of the twentieth century, the focus shifted to coal mining.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This geological map of three Tennessee counties (Davidson, Williamson, and Maury) shows main waterways, county seats and towns, main roads, geographical identifications, and transversal sections of the land. oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Dr. Gerard Troost
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This map was printed in the Seventh Report (to the Tennessee General Assembly) of Dr. G. Troost, State Geologist. Troost, a native of Holland, was Tennessee's first state geologist. He was a professor of chemistry, geology, and mineralogy at the University of Nashville for 22 years. For more information on Troost, consult the article in the Peabody Journal of Education 30, no. 5 (March 1953) by Ellen V. Piers, called "Girard Troost, Pioneer Scientist," pages 265-274.

The majority of farming families hired the services of mills to convert their grains to flour and meal. While water-powered mills were more common and efficient, other milling machines were mobile contraptions powered by oxen or other livestock. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This front-page obituary that appeared in the March 22, 1906, issue of the Manufacturers' Record for Joseph Buckner Killebrew highlighted his life-long devotion to agriculture. His contributions to the South with regard to agriculture, mining, industry and commerce, education, immigration, and the development of the railroads are emphasized, as well as his writings and editorships.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Manufacturers' Record, Baltimore, Md.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Manufacturers' Record was the leading business journal in the South during this time period. Editor Richard H. Edmonds sought to promote capital investment in the South and industrialization and used this paper as a tool. Killebrew was a regular contributor to this publication and, for the last eight years of his life, served on the editorial staff of the Southern Farm Magazine, also published by the Manufacturers' Record Publishing Co.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Tolbert Fanning, a leading Disciple of Christ and advocate of scientific agriculture, founded Franklin College in 1845 on the grounds of his farm at the present-day site of the Nashville International Airport. The agricultural school focused on classroom scientific study of agricuture, horticulture, and the mechanical arts; manual application in the fields; and religious study. Disrupted by the Civil War, the college was to reopen after the conflict, but was destroyed by fire.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1872, J. B. Killebrew (1831-1906) became the agricultural editor of the "Nashville Union and American." As a result in less than a year, a stock company was formed for the purpose of establishing the "Rural Sun," which first appeared in 1872 with Killebrew as editor-in-chief. The newspaper served as organ for the Tennessee Bureau of Agriculture, promoting immigration, development of timber and mineral resources and industrialization. The newspaper ceased publication in 1879.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The agricultural journal known as the Rural Record originated with this March 10, 1882, issue. Its target audience was to be the farmer, planter and stock raiser, and their families; thus, there were features that appealed to children and housewives as well. The company that published this journal was headed by Adolph S. Ochs, the businessman who cut his teeth on Chattanooga newspapers, later acquired the New York Times, and helped establish modern American journalism.

Collier of Charlotte, Tennessee, deals with encouraging immigration to Tennessee in the 1880s and the accompanying sale of farm land across the state. Killebrew assures Collier that immigration is not; just to East Tennessee that he matches requests for land to the need; and that counties must advertise resources to garner emigrants. The letter is written on letterhead from the Tennessee Bureau of Agriculture, Statistics, Mines and Immigration.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Killebrew had been pivotal in the establishment of a Bureau of Agriculture for Tennessee in 1871. He served as the Secretary and took charge of the Bureau's publications. When the Bureau was reorganized in 1875, Killebrew was named the first Commissioner of Agriculture; he served until 1880. The extended title of the Bureau appearing on the letterhead reveals the widespread responsibilites inherent in the development of agriculture in Tennessee.

In the antebellum period, many Tennessee farmers pursued what they thought would be a promising commercial opportunity in the production of silk. Fueling their optimism were discoveries in the 1830s that silkworms thrived on the native mulberry tree.These circumstances gave rise to a flurry of interest and activity in the 1830s and 1840s. In 1840 supporters formed the Tennessee Silk Society to promote production of cocoons and use of the fabric. Unfortunately, disease destroyed the small industry.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Ten page, soffcover, booklet detailing the advantages of settlement in Tennessee. The booklet describes the natural and man-made resources of Tennessee.

This type of promotional literature offered an important avenue to explore the historical development of Tennessee and the many opportunities for those interested in settlement. In the late 1890's and the early 1900's, promotional literature often championed the agricultural, the healthful and cathartic value of the Tennessee climate and geography. This booklet, completed in 1897, was sponsored by Tennessee's Bureau of Agriculture.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Agriculture; Mining; Emigration & immigration
Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hard-bound volume containing topographical, mineral, agricultural, economic, and social conditions about the state of Tennessee in order to promote immigration into the state.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A. W. Hawkins was the Tennessee Commissioner of Agriculture, Statistics, Mines and Immigration. For this book, he was assisted by Henry E. Colton, geologist and mining engineer.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oliver Tucker Seed Catalog
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Horticulture; Seed trade; Gardening; Farming; Seeds; Truck farming
Agriculture; Commercial catalogs
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A soft cover seed catalog. Both the cover and back page are in color. The cover has a photograph of a cotton field, as well as a photograph of Oliver F. Tucker. Page 3 has a phtograph of Tucker, as well as a listing of the directors of the company. The company's motto is listed: "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Oliver Tucker Seed Company
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: On September 1, 1926, the Oliver Tucker Seed Company was organized with Oliver F. Tucker as president. Tucker had bought out the interest in the Tucker-Mosby Seed Company.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Photograph of J. B. Killebrew
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Portrait photographs
Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image of J. B. Killebrew taken from the book, "Introduction to the Resources of Tennessee." The photograph was taken in 1871. The photo was taken in Nashville and the photographer was R. Poole. Killebrew appears to be middle-aged, and is wearing a suit. He has a beard and his hair is combed back. The book is volume one of a two-volume set. The book also contains an inscription from Killebrew to his son in 1875.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: J. B. Killebrew
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: J. B. Killebrew was the first Tennessee Commissioner of Agriculture and an advocate of the "New South." He was the agricultural editor of the "Nashville Union and American" and espoused views such as increased immigration to the South, improvement of public education, development of natural resources for industrialization, and the overall improvement of agriculture.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Crop Reports for Knox County
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Agriculture; Crop yields; Livestock; Agricultural laborers; Crop losses
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: These 1886 Average Crop Reports chart the county-by-county acreage, yield, condition, and damage of specific crops and livestock by local Tennessee farmers from April through November and offer them in comparision to the 1885 reports as an average. The wages of farm hands are also treated.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Department of Agriculture
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Record Group 15, Department of Agriculture Records
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: From the 1871 creation of the Bureau of Agriculture, the first incarnation of the Department of Agriculture, the gathering and publication of crop reports have been a primary responsibility of this entity. These county-by-county statistics have allowed for the evaluation of the State's agricultural capacity and potential.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ritual of the Farmer's Alliance
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Farmers' groups; Farmers; Fraternal organizations; Political organizations
Agriculture; National Farners' Alliance and Industrial Union; Nashville (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A small soft-cover booklet detailing the ritual for the installation of new members into the Farmers' Alliance. The booklet has been sewn together.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Farmers' Alliance
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Farmers' Alliance made its first appearance in Tennessee in the winter of 1887. In March 1888 farmers organized the Tennessee State Alliance and elected John P. Buchanan, a Rutherford County livestock man, as the first president. In 1889 the Farmers' Alliance joined the Agricultural Wheel to become the National Farmers' and Laborers' Union. The Alliance urged farmers to adopt scientific and business practices, diversify their crops, and become self-sufficient in order to break the debt cycle.
